thread.title: H.S. girls soccer: Fair Lawn bounces back with a flourish - Girls Soccer
thread.title_full: H.S. girls soccer: Fair Lawn bounces back with a flourish - Girls Soccer - NorthJersey.com

author: JIM HAGUE
title: H.S. girls soccer: Fair Lawn bounces back with a flourish - Girls Soccer
text:
FAIR LAWN – After enduring an emotional and heartbreaking loss to Immaculate Heart on Sunday in the Bergen County tournament quarterfinals, the Fair Lawn girls soccer team had to turn around and face Big North Independence Division rival Lakeland 24 hours later.
Was there concern over that?
"Sure, there were obvious concerns," Fair Lawn coach John Van Soest said. "I was concerned whether we were going to be able to play on an emotional level and a physical level against one of the top teams in our division. Lakeland always gives us a tough game. I had to stress the importance of the game and hoped that there wouldn’t be a hangover from Sunday."
The Cutters took IHA through regulation, two overtimes, and finally succumbed to the higher seed via penalty kicks. But that loss Sunday seemed to trigger something within the Cutters.
"[Sunday] was a big confidence booster for us," said senior midfielder Lisa Kestelboym, who snapped a scoreless tie with a header in the 66th minute, leading Fair Lawn to a 2-0 victory over the Lancers on Monday. 
"We didn’t think the game [Sunday] had a negative effect on us at all," said Kestelboym, who perfectly timed a corner kick from Allison Hyde to break the scoreless deadlock.
"I thought it gave us confidence and momentum coming into this one. It’s what we needed if we wanted to get an upper hand on this one."
After Kestelboym broke the scoreless drought, the Cutters scored again on an unusual goal.
Senior forward Vicki Telewiak had a throw-in from the right side with 6:46 left and somehow managed to throw it right into the net off a deflection from Lakeland keeper Jenna Bracken.
"I never saw that happen before," Telewiak said.
"I was just throwing it to make a play, so I threw it into the box. The fact that it went in amazed me, but it gave me the best feeling in the world."
Telewiak also didn’t think that there was any negative carryover from the tough loss to IHA.
"We played IHA tough and tried our best," Telewiak said. "Sure, we were all a little tired and our legs were restless. But we all knew we could control the game. How much we wanted this game was the motivation behind it."
The Cutters (9-3) scored their two goals off set pieces — a corner kick and a throw-in. It’s not uncommon for them to score in that fashion.
"We’re not going to beat teams with give-and-goes," Van Soest said. "We’re all about corners and throw-ins. We win the corners and win the throws."
"Whoever’s closest to the header takes it," Kestelboym said.
The Lancers (9-3) had some early scoring chances, but Fair Lawn goalkeeper Brianna Meitzler kept the Lancers off the board by making some good saves early, then remained steady throughout.
Meitzler thwarted a scoring chance with 13 minutes left, when Lakeland junior Maddie Burgner had a diving attempt all alone in front. Meitzler came out of net to pounce on the loose ball. She had 10 saves. 
Bracken was equally up to the challenge, making nine saves, one of which came in the 36th minute that would have given Fair Lawn a lead at the half.
"In the first half, I thought we had more scoring opportunities," Lakeland head coach Rick Capozzi said.
"We had about three or four opportunities and couldn’t put one in the net. Give Fair Lawn credit. They came out and wanted it more than us. I’m surprised how well they came back after [Sunday]."
